newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Police free Timorese who occupied Austrian mission.
newsitem.headline: Police free Timorese who occupied Austrian mission.

text.p: Indonesian police on Tuesday freed 33 East Timorese youths who spent several days in custody after they broke into the Austrian Embassy in Jakarta last week as part of a successful bid to meet a visiting U.N. envoy.
"All 33 have been released...earlier today. They have left for Semarang, Surabaya and Yogyakarta using public transport," a policewoman at the metropolitan police headquarters said.
"They will not be charged or taken to court. There are no conditions for their release," she told Reuters.

East Timorese sources said they had confirmed that eight members of the group who were being held in cells at South Jakarta police headquarters had telephoned from a bus station on their way home to Yogyakarta in Central Java.
They added they had not yet heard from the remaining 25.

The youths entered the embassy compound last Tuesday and demanded to see Jamsheed Marker, the U.N. secretary-general's special envoy on East Timor who was in Jakarta on a familiarisation trip to Indonesia and East Timor.
Only hours after the break-in, three of the youths were taken to meet Marker at United Nations offices in Jakarta.
Austrian Ambassador Hans Demel said the youths left the embassy early last Thursday after an agreement with senior officials of the Indonesian Department of Foreign Affairs.
Demel had said he expected the youths to be held for only a few hours.

"They were held for so long as the police tried to get them to sign a statement recognising East Timor as an integrated part of Indonesia. They refused to sign the statements and in the end the police had to let them go," an East Timorese source said.

In a similar protest in December 1995 at the Dutch Embassy, police held about 50 mostly East Timorese protesters for 24 hours before they were released. A similar number who entered the Russian Embassy were held for the same amount of time.
Since September 1995, 108 East Timorese have entered foreign embassies in Jakarta and asked for political asylum, always granted by Portugal, the former colonial ruler of East Timor.
Indonesia invaded East Timor in 1975 and annexed it the following year in a move not recognised by the United Nations.
